titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Joseph Brodsky Papers document the life and work of Russian-born poet, essayist and Nobel Laureate Joseph Brodsky, with a particular emphasis on the time period of his residence in the United States (1972-1996). The papers consist of correspondence, writings, personal papers (including legal, medical and financial records), audiovisual material, teaching material, student papers, newspaper clippings and printed ephemera, spanning the years 1890-2004, with the bulk of the material dating from the period 1972-1996.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund from Lame Duck Books in 2004. One box was donated by the Estate of Joseph Brodsky in 2005.

According to a letter in her correspondence (April 1996), Ann Kjellberg (Joseph Brodsky's assistant and, after his death, literary executor) began to assemble an archive of Brodsky's papers in 1991. This effort continued after his death in 1996. Friends and associates of Brodsky (George Kline, Carl Proffer, Masha Vorobiov and others) sent Kjellberg originals and photocopies of papers to be included in the archive. Provenance of individual items can sometimes be traced by Kjellberg's or others' notes on the material.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Access to some material is restricted, as detailed in the following paragraphs. Consult the appropriate curator for more information.
Letters of Recommendation (Boxes 21-22), Student Papers (Boxes 127-131) and Restricted Papers (Boxes 214-217) are restricted until 2071.
The notebooks in Box 40 are partially restricted until 2071. Access to the original notebooks is restricted. A microfilm of unrestricted pages is available.
Boxes 168-169, 171-176, 220-225, and 232 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

Boxes 218-219, 226 and 233-241: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies are available for electronic documents. Consult Access Services for further information. For other materials, reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Joseph Brodsky Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Joseph Brodsky Papers. Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was formerly classed as Uncat.MSS 649, Uncat.MSS 766, Uncat.MSS 876 and Uncat.MSS 926.

The Library of Congress system is used to transliterate Russian, but diacritics are not used. Illustrative examples are: Iuz Aleshkovskii and Efim Etkind. Names of Russian emigres are spelled in accordance with the individual's usage or record of publication. Therefore these spellings do not necessarily conform to standard Library of Congress transliteration. For example, the spelling Joseph Brodsky is used throughout the finding aid, while Brodsky's parents are referred to as Aleksandr Brodskii and Mariia Brodskaia.
Electronic files were refreshed into the Yale University Library Rescue Repository. Technical specifications are filed with the media in Restricted Fragile.
Boxes 227-231 and folders 3767-3822 and 4710-4758 are unused. Original videocassettes are now housed in boxes 171-176. Restricted fragile material.

Boxes 161-165 and folders 3645-3717, 3750-3753, 3760-3762, 3764-3766 are unused. Original audiocassettes and reel-to-reel audiotapes are now housed in boxes 220-225 and 232. Restricted fragile material.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Portions of the collection are available on microfilm.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Printed material received with the collection was removed for separate cataloging and can be accessed by searching the library's online catalog.

bioghist.head: Joseph Brodsky, 1940-1996
bioghist.p: Joseph Brodsky, Russian-born poet, essayist and Nobel Laureate, was born in Leningrad on May 24, 1940 to Aleksandr Ivanovich Brodskii and Mariia Moiseevna Brodskaia (nee Vol'pert). His birth was just one year before the start of the Leningrad Blockade; thus his early years were ones of extreme hardship. The Brodsky family's Jewish heritage exposed them to the anti-Semitic atmosphere of the post-war Soviet Union, causing Aleksandr Ivanovich to lose his rank in the Army and preventing Joseph from entering into the submarine academy. The communal apartment where Brodsky lived with his parents (and where his parents lived until their deaths) was memorialized in his essay "A room and a half."

Joseph Brodsky ended his formal schooling by walking out of his public school classroom at age fifteen and worked in a variety of places, including a factory, a morgue, and on geological expiditions. He began to write poetry in his teens and soon demonstrated a keen interest in translation. He taught himself Polish and English in order to translate poetry, including that of Czesław Miłosz and John Donne. Brodsky's Russian literary influences included Anna Akhmatova, Osip Mandelshtam, Boris Pasternak and Marina Tsvetaeva. His early writings in Russia were circulated in samizdat (self-published) collections, the most complete one compiled by Vladimir Maramzin.

Brodsky was arrested several times starting in 1961, tried in 1964 as a "social parasite" (tuneiadets), and sentenced to five years of labor in Norenskaia (a village in the Arkhangelsk Province of northern Russia). Brodsky lived in Norenskaia from March of 1964 to October of 1965 and wrote prolificly there. Brodsky's trial and sentence brought him increasing international attention when Frida Vigdorova's transcript was publicized in the Western media. It was also around this time that his poetry began to be compiled and published in the United States. Stikhotvoreniia i Poemy (Washington, D.C. & New York: Inter-Language Literary Associates) was published in in 1965, followed by Ostanovka v pustyne (New York: Izdatel'stvo imeni Chekhova) in 1970. Even after his release from Norenskaia, Brodsky continued to be at constant risk of arrest. In 1972 he was forced to emigrate when he was suddenly granted a visa (for which he had not applied) to emigrate to Israel. He had to leave Russia within a matter of weeks.

Brodsky traveled to Austria, where he stayed with W.H. Auden for several weeks, and to England before coming to the United Sates. He accepted a position as Poet in Residence at the University of Michigan (a post that Carl Proffer, founder of Ardis Publishing, was instrumental in securing). Brodsky taught at Michigan until 1981, when he accepted a permanent position on the faculty of Mount Holyoke College. He then divided his time between New York City and South Hadley, Massachusetts. He became a United States citizen in 1977. Brodsky never returned to Russia after emigrating, though later in his life political circumstances would have allowed it and his Russian readers clamored for it.

Among Brodsky's many awards and honors are a John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation Fellowship (1977), a John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation award (1981), a National Book Critics Circle award (1986), the Nobel Prize in Literature (1987), France's Order of the Legion of Honor (1991), and honorary degrees from Yale University (1978), Dartmouth College (1989), and Oxford University (1991). He was Poet Laureate of the United States from 1991 to 1992.
Brodsky suffered from heart disease throughout his adult life and he had several open-heart surgeries. He died of heart failure on January 28, 1996.

During his lifetime, much of Brodsky's collected poetry and prose was published by Ardis in Ann Arbor, Michigan (Russian-language poetry) and Farrar, Straus and Giroux in New York (English-language poetry, English translations and prose collections). Brodsky's major publications from 1977 to 2000 include:

list.item: A Part of Speech (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1980)
Novye stansy k Avguste: Stikhi k M.B., 1962-1982 (Ardis, 1983)
Less Than One: Selected Essays (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1986)
To Urania: Selected Poems 1965-1985 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1988)
On Grief and Reason: Essays (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 1995)
Peizazh s navodneniem (Dana Point, California: Ardis, 1996)
Collected Poems in English, 1972-1999 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 2000)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Joseph Brodsky Papers document the life and work of Russian-born poet, essayist and Nobel Laureate Joseph Brodsky. The papers consist of correspondence, writings, personal papers (including legal, medical and financial records), audiovisual material, teaching material, student papers, newspaper clippings and printed ephemera, spanning the years 1890-2004, with the bulk of the material dating from the period 1972-1996.

The papers document all aspects of Brodsky's professional life, including writings, appearances, readings, lectures, advocacy and relations with other literary figures. The research interest of the papers encompasses Russian-language poetry, the Soviet emigre experience, and poetry translation. Researchers interested in Brodsky's creative process will find much relevant material, including multiple drafts (many corrected) of poems and essays (including translations by Brodsky and others). Teaching material is present in small quantities and provides only sporadic documentation of Brodsky's career as an educator. Personal papers are also present and chiefly document immigration and other legal affairs.

Brodsky's work, while rarely political, reflects broad historical and political themes that defined his era: empire, emigration, and the relationship of the individual to the state. The trajectory of Brodsky's publishing and teaching is inextricable from the emigre experience, as his early works were censored in the Soviet Union and promoted by publishers and scholars in the United States. After the fall of the Soviet Union, the Russian literary public was able to "reclaim" Brodsky openly and his works (including Russian translations of his essays) were published there.

Brodsky's bilingual emigre identity is elucidated in his writings. A significant proportion of Brodsky's poetry was translated from Russian to English, often by multiple translators, and some poems exist in alternate versions. Brodsky's prose was also oft-translated: his early essays were written in Russian and translated into English, though most of his prose was written in English. While Brodsky's notes and corrections indicate engagement with the translation of his prose, it is evident that his commitment to and involvement in the translation of his poetry was profound.

Brodsky's personal papers document his bitter struggle with American and Soviet bureaucracies as he tried first to have his parents visit him in the United States and then to attend his father's funeral. After emigration, as evidenced particularly in his letters to editors, Brodsky lent his international acclaim to the cause of politically persecuted literary figures in the Soviet Union and elsewhere.

Brodsky's literary milieu, like his life and work, was transnational and multilingual. Correspondence, writings and audiovisual recordings document his close relationships with fellow Nobel Laureates Seamus Heaney, Czesław Miłosz and Derek Walcott and with English-language poets Anthony Hecht and Mark Strand, among others. Many of these poets translated Brodsky's poetry or dedicated poems to Brodsky in memorium. Hundreds of aspiring and accomplished Russian-language poets also sent him manuscripts, as evidenced in Writings of Others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eleven series: I. Correspondence, 1964-2004. II. Writings, 1959-2000. III. Interviews and Speeches, 1974-1996. IV. Teaching Material and Student Papers, 1973-1995. V. Personal Papers, 1961-2000. VI. Photographs, 1890-2001. VII. Audiovisual Material, 1953-2002. VIII. Clippings, 1964-2002. IX. Printed Material, 1920-2003. X. Artwork, 1972-1986. XI. Papers of Others, 1912-2000.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is organized into three subseries: General Correspondence, Letters of Recommendation, and Ann Kjellberg Correspondence.

Correspondence relates chiefly to Brodsky's writings, to readings and speaking engagements, to human rights advocacy (particularly as it relates to literary figures), and to affairs of the Russian emigre community in the United States.

General Correspondence includes fan letters and letters soliciting Brodsky's opinion about manuscripts, primarily poems in English and in Russian. Manuscripts unaccompanied by letters, or accompanied by routine letters, are filed in Writings of Others (Boxes 103-121) .

While most of the correspondence dates from after Brodsky's 1972 emigration to the United States, there is some documentation of Brodsky's life in the Soviet Union and his emigration experience. A letter from Brodsky's father Aleksandr Brodskii (Box 3, folders 71-71, circa 1965) documents Brodskii's efforts to advocate for his son. Another 1965 letter in support of Brodsky (Chukovskii et al., Box 3, folder 92) is signed by over a dozen prominent literary figures. Letters from Sergei Shults (Box 14, folder 368) include notes about Brodsky's 1964 trial. A folder of telegrams to Brodsky in Kirchstetten in 1972 (Box 18, folders 470-497) demonstrates Brodsky's connections with and support from European and American literary figures at the time of his emigration.

Correspondence from the years immediately after Brodsky's emigration chiefly document his search for a permanent position at a University and the translation and publication of his works. Letters from individuals such as Masha Vorobiov, George Kline (translator) and Carl Proffer (publisher) document their assistance to Brodsky in these domains.

Later correspondence (from the 1980s and 1990s) addresses a wider range of topics and includes more purely professional requests (e.g. requests for appearances and requests to read manuscripts). The correspondence also documents Brodsky's continued commitment to advocacy on behalf of authors who are persecuted for political reasons.
Little of the correspondence is purely personal in nature and there are few family letters.

From the 1980s on, much of Brodsky's correspondence was managed by his assistants Aleksandr Sumerkin and Ann Kjellberg. Sumerkin managed the Russian-language correspondence, while Kjellberg managed the English-language correspondence. Correspondence managed by Brodsky's assistant Aleksandr Sumerkin is interfiled in General Correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically. Files for correspondents identified by first name only and unidentified correspondents follow the main alphabetic listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ann Kjellberg, an editor who has worked at Farrar, Straus and Giroux and The New York Review of Books , became Brodsky's assistant in 1986. Following his death in 1996, Kjellberg became Executor and Trustee in the Estate of Joseph Brodsky.

Ann Kjellberg Correspondence relates to Brodsky's appearances, speaking engagements and the editing and publication of Brodsky's writings. Other papers found in Ann Kjellberg Correspondence consist of itineraries and schedules, phone numbers, addresses, and blank papers with Brodsky's signature.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically. Most files contain bundles of letters with different dates stapled together, reflecting Kjellberg's organization of the correspondence. The bundles constitute the correspondence about a single topic or with a single person. These bundles are filed according to the date on the top letter, which usually indicates the date on which the correspondence concluded. Therefore the dates on a folder do not always reflect the dates of every letter in a file.
Undated correspondence from each year is filed at the end of the year. Undated correspondence with no year is filed at the end of the subseries, after dated correspondence.
Other papers found in Ann Kjellberg correspondence are filed at the end of the subseries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Also available through Access Services: Disk#02; REJ, REJECT and REJMERGE.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is organized into six subseries: Notebooks, Poetry, Prose, Dramatic Writing, Collected Works and Writings of Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II includes holograph and typescript drafts, proofs and printed versions of Brodsky's poetry, prose and other writings. Brodsky's early (pre-1972) poetry is documented sporadically, while the material for his poetry, prose and drama written after emigration (1972-1996) is far more complete. The Series includes material from works in progress at the time of Brodsky's death (e.g. So Forth ) and for some posthumously printed works (e.g. Collected Poems in English , edited by Ann Kjellberg).

Some drafts, proofs and printed versions are corrected by Brodsky, Ann Kjellberg, Masha Vorobiov or one of the several translators with whom Brodsky worked closely. Translations are filed under a single heading with the original work, reflecting the involvement that Brodsky often had in the translation process. Translators are identified by name when the information is available. Some poetry translations by unidentified translators are likely by Brodsky.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Notebooks in Box 40 are partially restricted. Access to the original notebooks is restricted. A microfilm of unrestricted pages is available. See MS Vault Film 2524.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged roughly chronologically. Undated notebooks are filed after the main listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As detailed in folder-level notes, the notebooks contain holograph drafts of writings and letters, daily to-do lists, phone numbers and addresses, and other personal notes. The folder-level notes are not exhaustive but indicative of the contents of each notebook. The notebooks are almost entirely in Brodsky's hand; only rarely is other handwriting present.
Dates of the notebooks in this Subseries are tentative. Many notebooks span several years and Brodsky may have revisited them at later dates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poetry consists of holograph and typescript drafts, proofs, and printed versions of poems and poetry collections. Some material is photocopies. Though several samizdat collections date to before Brodsky's emigration from the Soviet Union and some printed collections date to after his death, most material dates from 1972-1996.

Brodsky's poetry spans a wide range of genres, including children's poems, occasionals, short and long poems (stikhotvoreniia and poemy) and cycles. Many of the English-language translations of Brodsky's poetry are autotranslations and he also collaborated with others to produce authorized English translations. While most of his poetry was written in Russian, some of his later poems were English-language originals.

Printed Collections are book-length collections of Brodsky's poems, compiled by Brodsky and editors. Samizdat Collections are book-length collections that circulated in the Soviet Union without being formally published. Printed Selections consist of selected poems that were printed in serials or compilations. Individual Poems include drafts, proofs and printed versions of poems outside the context of collections. Many of these poems also appeared in printed collections or selections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Poetry is organized under four headings: Printed Collections, Samizdat Collections, Printed Selections, and Individual Poems. Printed Collections are arranged alphabetically by title of work. Samizdat Collections are arranged roughly chronologically. Printed Selections are arranged alphabetically by title of the publication in which the poetry was printed. Individual Poems are arranged alphabetically by title or, for untitled poems, by first line. Unidentified collections, selections and poems are filed at the end of each listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Individual Poems are holograph and typescript drafts, proofs and printed versions outside the context of a printed collection. Some drafts are photocopies. Printed versions include clippings and photocopies from serials such as The New Yorker and The Times Literary Supplement.
Translators are identified where their names are in evidence.
Dates in square brackets are informed by Sochineniia Iosifa Brodskogo . Other details such as dates and names of translators have occasionally been verified in Collected Poems in English .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title or, for untitled poems, first line. The first line of an untitled poem is indicated by quotation marks (e.g. "A potom nachalsia snegopad"). Untitled poems beginning with the articles "a" and "the" are filed under these words (e.g. "The water gets colder as the ocean heaves" is filed under the, while The tale is filed under tale). Translations of Brodsky's poems are collated with originals under the original-language title. Translations of others' poems by Brodsky are filed according to the English- or Russian-language title of Brodsky's translation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Masha Vorobiov gave this material to Ann Kjellberg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prose consists of holograph and typescript drafts, proofs, and printed versions of essays, introductions and afterwords, letters to editors, short fiction and collections of prose writing. While most material is original, there are some photocopies. Brodsky's prose writing chiefly consists of analysis of classical and contemporary poets. Among his most celebrated essays are "On Grief and Reason" (on Robert Frost), Watermark (reflections on the city of Venice), and the memoirs "Less than one" and "In a room and a half." Most of Brodsky's prose writing after 1974 is in English and (unlike his poetry) he generally did not translate it himself.

Printed Collections are book-length collections of essays, all of which were published during Brodsky's lifetime by Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Individual Prose Writings are essays, introductions and afterwords, letters to editors and short fiction outside the context of a printed collection. Many of these essays appeared in serial publications such as Times Literary Supplement and New Yorker .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prose is organized under two headings: Printed Collections and Individual Prose Writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Individual Prose Writings are further organized under four headings: Essays, Introductions and Afterwords to Others' Work, Letters to Editors, and Short Fiction. Essays are arranged alphabetically by title. Introductions to Others' Work are arranged alphabetically by the name of the author being introduced or by title (for volumes without a single author). Letters to Editors are arranged chronologically. Short fiction is arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collected Works consists of a multi-volume samizdat collection and a multi-volume printed series that collect several genres of Brodsky's writing. The samizdat collection compiled by Vladimir Maramzin contains the most complete documentation of Brodsky's pre-emigration writings. The material from Sochineniia Iosifa Brodskogo (primarily consisting of proofs) is fragmentary but includes some material that does not appear in the final printed volumes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings of Others consists of holograph and typescript drafts of writings that the authors sent or gave to Brodsky. Many of these writings were sent by fans seeking Brodsky's opinion on their manuscripts; others were sent by former students and friends. The manuscripts contain chiefly poetry, but also include some essays, novels and dramatic works.
Photocopies of printed writings are filed in Series IX, Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interviews and Speeches consists of transcripts, drafts and printed versions of interviews by and with Brodsky and for speeches that Brodsky delivered. Interviews by Brodsky (with Czesław Miłosz and Derek Walcott, two poets of great importance in Brodsky's life) focus on literary influences of his interview subjects. Interviews with Brodsky address Brodsky's writing and his analysis of literature, and rarely focus on personal or political affairs. Speeches include short introductions of others as well as longer discourses on literary topics. Brodsky's Nobel Prize acceptance speech is filed in this series, but his Nobel Lecture is filed in Series II, Writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is organized into three subseries: Interviews by Brodsky, Interviews with Brodsky, and Speeches. Unidentified interviews and speeches are filed at the end of each subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Teaching material includes background material and documents associated with courses Brodsky taught, including syllabi, course descriptions, and photocopies of curricular material. The papers are not comprehensive enough or of sufficient quantity to thoroughly document Brodsky's teaching activity. Student papers consists of papers written by students for Brodsky's courses at Columbia, Mount Holyoke and elsewhere.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Certificates, diplomas and honorary medals document the honorary degrees Brodsky received from several institutions. Brodsky's Nobel Medal is not present in the collection. Drawings by Brodsky are sketches in pen and ink and include self-portraits, portraits of others and allegorical scenes. Calendars and date books contain informal daily notes, phone numbers, addresses and information about travel itineraries and appointments. Medical papers include medical bills and records. Financial papers include bills, bank records and receipts. Legal papers include documentation of Brodsky's emigration and of his efforts to assist other emigres (including his efforts to obtain a visa for his parents to visit the United States). Inscriptions consist of photocopies of book dedications that others sent to Brodsky or to Ann Kjellberg. Other papers include personal notes that chiefly relate to daily activities and papers found in Brodsky's homes and offices (including some small printed artwork).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is organized into five subseries: Joseph Brodsky, Family (including Brodsky as a child), Other People, Places and Other Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs span a wide range of styles, locations and subjects and document Brodsky's life from his childhood to his death, memorial and burial in 1996.

Photographs of Joseph Brodsky comprise the bulk of the series and include professional portraits, snapshots and photographs with others. The settings for professional portraits include studios and Brodsky's homes and offices. Snapshots were taken by Brodsky and by his friends, including Veronique Schlitz and Masha Vorobiov. The heading Posthumous Photographs includes Brodsky's memorial, grave site, and South Hadley home at the time of Brodsky's death.

Family Photographs date chiefly from Brodsky's childhood and there are very few photographs of his wife Maria Sozzani Brodsky and daughter Anna. There are no photographs of Brodsky's son Andrei Basmanov.
Other People does not include Brodsky, although some of these snapshots may have been taken at events where Brodsky was present, or may have been taken by Brodsky.
Places consists of photographs that do not depict known people, but were apparently taken while Brodsky was traveling, or to document his home and work environment.
Other Photographs includes Brodsky's cats, art objects and unidentified subjects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name of photographer. Portraits by unidentified photographers are filed at the end of the listing.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Boxes 169, 171-176, 220-225 and 232 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information. Access copies of some recordings are filed in this series. All original recordings are filed in Restricted Fragile.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Audiovisual material consists of two subseries: Audio material and Video material. Each subseries is further organized under the headings Recordings of Joseph Brodsky, Other Recordings and Unidentified Recordings. Material is arranged chronologically under each heading; undated material is filed at the end of each listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audiovisual material consists of recordings of interviews, lectures and poetry readings featuring Brodsky and recordings related to or dedicated to Brodsky. Folder descriptions are based on labels and notes accompanying the recordings and the contents have not been fully verified. Audio recordings are 0.15 inch cassettes unless otherwise noted; video recordings are VHS cassettes unless otherwise noted.

did.unittitle: "A Tune for Bosnia," studio and live recordings in Munich
did.materialspec: Left-channel audio is low until 4:46. Right-channel audio is low from 4:46-13:49.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A note from Joseph De Luca, dated 1994-25-04, is written on the audiocassette's liner insert. It reads: Dear Mr. Brodsky, Here's the real thing for you! Thanks for your postcard, it was one of the greatest joys of my life to receive it. Martha was surprised & pleased. She complained that you write to me but not to her! I'm sorry for the crime of having sung "Sister Dove" instead of "Brother Slav". I just thought that the victims are mainly muslims, though I don't know exactly if the Bosnian muslims are also Slav or Turkish or mixed. I don't know, I'm sorry, "Sister Dove" just came to me, sorry for destoying your beautiful Love-Slav thing.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is organized under two headings: Clippings related to Brodsky and Other Clippings. Material is arranged chronologically under each heading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clippings related to Brodsky consists of newspaper and magazine articles that are directly about Brodsky or his writings. Articles include profiles, announcements and reviews of his writings. Other Clippings include magazines and serials that do not contain any article directly related to Brodsky. Some serials include articles on Russian culture or literature that do not mention Brodsky.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is organized into two subseries: Copies of Articles and Ephemera. Copies of Articles is arranged alphabetically by author. Ephemera is further organized under two headings: Ephemera related to Brodsky and Other Ephemera. Ephemera is arranged chronologically under each heading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of articles consist of photocopies from journals and volumes related to literature, primarily poetry. Many of the articles relate to topics and poets of particular interest to Brodsky, such as Constantine Cavafy and Marina Tsvetaeva. Ephemera includes posters, flyers, catalogs and postcards. Ephemera Related to Brodsky documents Brodsky's poetry readings, appearances and publications as well as memorials, exhibits and other events dedicated to Brodsky. Other Ephemera includes blank postcards, catalogs from exhibitions that Brodsky may have attended, and publisher's catalogs that do not include Brodsky's writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by author.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is organized into four Subseries: Masha Vorobiov Papers, Carl and Ellendea Proffer Papers, George Kline Papers and Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of papers sent to Ann Kjellberg to be included in Brodsky's archive.

Masha Vorobiov was a friend of Brodsky and sometimes acted as assistant and translator. She taught Russian Language and Literature at Vassar College from 1977-2000 and died in 2001 at the age of 67. Carl and Ellendea Proffer founded Ardis Press in Ann Arbor Michigan and were instrumental in publishing much of Brodsky's Russian-language poetry in the United States. George Kline taught at Bryn Mawr College and translated several of Brodsky's poems from Russian to English.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Masha Vorobiov Papers are organized under four headings: Correspondence, Writings, Printed Material and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Masha Vorobiov contributed substantially to the archive of Brodsky's correspondence and writings. Material of Brodsky's that was in Vorobiov's possession is interfiled in Series I. Writings and Series II. Correspondence. This subseries consists of Voribiov's own papers, most of which relate to Brodsky.

Masha Voribiov Papers include correspondence, notes and photocopies of articles. Correspondence is incoming unless otherwise indicated. Most correspondence relates to the publication of Brodsky's writings or events dedicated to Brodsky. Notes are more personal in nature and include phone numbers, addresses, travel itineraries and medical information. Printed material includes photocopies of journal articles and book excerpts related to Brodsky and to literature generally.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically. Unidentified correspondence is filed at the end of the listing.

did.physloc: Also stored in: Oversize Box 211, folder 4435

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carl and Ellendea Proffer Papers include correspondence, notes and newspaper clippings. Correspondence (incoming and outgoing) relates to Ardis Press, Russian Literature Triquarterly and to Vladimir Maramzin. Notes relate to Carl Proffer's translations of Brodsky's works. Material related to the campaign to release Vladimir Maramzin from prison in the Soviet Union includes open letters, newspaper clippings and a transcript of Maramzin's trial in 1974. Maramzin was imprisoned on charges related to the compilation Joseph Brodsky's writings and to the distribution of Maramzin's own writings.

did.unittitle: Broadside, unidentified author, occasional poem to Joseph Brodsky

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Begins "Dear Joseph Brodsky, Russian friend and dear/ To mourn and celebrate we gather here." Written for the occasion of Brodsky's departure from Michigan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes notes on Carl Proffer's English translation of Sonnet , an unidentified poem and an unidentified prose writing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Kline Papers include correspondence, holograph drafts of poems by Brodsky and an occasional poem to Brodsky. Correspondence relates to Brodsky's condition in the Soviet Union before emigration and to the publication of Kline's translations. The holograph drafts were written in the notebook of Kathy Gibson, a student who visited Brodsky in Leningrad in 1969.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes holograph drafts of Brodsky's poems S fevral'ia po aprel' , Zimnim vecherom v Ialte and Pochti elegiia .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ann-Ellen Akeley was a graduate student student in the Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures at the University of Michigan in the mid-1970s. The Papers consist of copies of clippings and ephemera that document Brodsky's teaching and appearances, mostly in Michigan in the 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bengt Jangfeldt was Brodsky's Swedish language translator. The Papers consist of photocopies of manuscripts and letters from Brodsky in Jangfeldt's personal archive and a list of other papers in Jangfeldt's archive.

did.unittitle: Ramunas and Elmira Katilius family archive

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of photocopies of manuscripts from the Ramunas and Elmira Katilius family archive in Vilnius, Lithuania.

did.unittitle: Ann Kjellberg notes on a reading group

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ann Kjellberg was Brodsky's assistant from 1986 to 1996 and became his literary executor after his death. Kjellberg organized a reading group that focused on Brodsky's poetry in English.

did.unittitle: Catalog of Brodsky photographs from the M. I. Mil'chik collection

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The M. I. Mil'chik collection of photographs is not part of the Joseph Brodsky Papers. The catalog describes the collection of photographs held by Mil'chik and includes thumbnail reproductions of each photograph. Before his death in 1984, Aleksandr Ivanovich Brodskii (Joseph Brodsky's father) gave the bulk of the collection to Mil'chik, who continued to add to it.

did.unittitle: Lydia Rubin correspondence with John Lew

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On translating Russian poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sergei Shul'ts was a geologist and poet. The Papers consist of photocopies of letters from Brodsky to Shults, Brodsky's annotations on manuscripts of Shults' poetry and clippings from Leningrad newspapers, and papers related to Brodsky's interrogation and trial in the Soviet Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kees Verheul was Brodsky's Dutch translator. The Papers consist of copies of letters and drafts of poems the Verheul donated to the Literary Museum of the Netherlands. Some manuscripts are illustrated with original drawings by Brodsky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Peter Viereck was a poet and professor of History at Mount Holyoke College. The Papers consist of photocopies of material related to Brodsky and a cover letter to Ann Kjellberg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notebooks contain drafts of writings and letters.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies are available for electronic documents. Consult Access Services for further information. For other materials, reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Boxes 161-162, 227-231 and folders 3646-3667, 3767-3822 and 4710-4758 are unused. Original videocassettes are now housed in Boxes 171-176.
